chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess suspected Achilles tendinopathy?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Ask about symptoms that might indicate Achilles tendon rupture, such as sudden pain in the back of the leg, an audible snap, and difficulty weight bearing.
  • Ask about typical symptoms of Achilles tendinopathy, including:
    • Aching (occasionally sharp) pain in the heel. This may be preceded by an excessive mechanical stressor.
      • Pain is aggravated by activity or pressure to the area.
      • Gradual onset of pain 2–6 cm proximal to the Achilles tendon insertion that limits activity suggests mid-portion Achilles tendinopathy.
      • Pain and swelling at the insertion to the posterior calcaneus with impairment of function suggests insertional tendinopathy.
      • Some people may present with symptoms at both the insertion and mid-portion.
    • Stiffness in the tendon.
      • Stiffness may occur in the morning or after a period of prolonged sitting.
  • The Victorian Institute of Sports Assessment-Achilles (VISA-A) questionnaire can be used to assess pain and symptom severity with activity in people with Achilles tendinopathy.
  • Ask about risk factors such as diabetes mellitus, dyslipidaemia, and fluoroquinolone use.
  • Examine both legs. Exclude Achilles tendon rupture. If no evidence of an Achilles tendon rupture is found:
    • Look for redness, swelling, and asymmetry.
    • Palpate along the length of the tendon for tenderness, heat, crepitus, thickening, and nodularity.
      • Tenderness on palpation of the mid-portion of the tendon is indicative of mid-portion Achilles tendinopathy.
      • Tenderness on palpation around the distal 2 cm of the tendon is usually found in insertional Achilles tendinopathy.
    • Evaluate the range of motion of the ankle. Pain worsens with passive dorsiflexion of the ankle. 
    • Assess function by asking the person to perform physical tasks such as hop and heel-raise endurance tests, as appropriate.
  • Achilles tendinopathy is usually a clinical diagnosis and imaging (such as ultrasound or MRI) is not routinely recommended in primary care.
  • Arrange investigations (such as lipid profile or HbA1c) as appropriate, if an underlying cause is suspected.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the diagnosis of Achilles tendon rupture and Achilles tendinopathy are based on the US clinical guideline Achilles pain, stiffness, and muscle power deficits: midportion Achilles tendinopathy revision 2018 [Martin, 2018], and expert opinion in the review articles Achilles tendon rupture [Boyd, 2015], Everything Achilles: knowledge update and current concepts in management: AAOS exhibit selection [Uquillas, 2015], Pain at the back of the heel [Morton, 2016], Treatment of Achilles tendinopathy: state of the art [Ackermann, 2018b], Common running injuries: evaluation and management [Arnold, 2018], Heel pain: diagnosis and management [Tu, 2018], and Achilles insertional tendinopathy: state of the art [Maffulli, 2019].  
  • The recommendations on asking about risk factors and arranging investigations as appropriate if an underlying cause is suspected are pragmatic and based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
